http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Theatre I is a two-semester course in which students learn and demonstrate mastery of theatre academic and performance skills. Theatre II and III are two-semester courses which expand the knowledge and performance base of Theatre I. At the Theatre I level, students will explore theatre fundamentals, analyze and interpret scripts, evaluate artistic work, and use those evaluations to deepen the meaning of their work. In Theatre II and III students will focus on the practical application of skills developed in Theatre I. Students will take on more complex projects and may begin to develop directorial skills. Ultimately, students will make artistic decisions using multiple forms of inspiration, particularly focusing on social, cultural, and historical context. Theatre I contains an introduction to stagecraft skills. Theatre II and III do not develop these stagecraft skills, but the teacher may choose to draw student learning expectations from the Stagecraft I-III Curriculum Framework. Theatre I fulfills the one-half credit fine arts required for graduation. Arkansas Department of Education approval is not required for Theatre I, Theatre II, and Theatre III.
Creating
Students will generate and conceptualize artistic ideas and work.
Explore given imaginary environments through dramatic activities (e.g., pantomime, mime, improvisation) to develop diverse characters
Explore the collaborative nature of theatre

Generate a design, following the steps of the design process
  • analysis
  • research
  • preliminary sketches
Utilize a design morgue to inform design choices
Students will organize and develop artistic ideas and work.
Develop characters, environments, and actions individually in a devised or scripted drama/theatre work

Identify stage directions
  • center stage
  • downstage
  • stage left
  • stage right
  • upstage

Identify different onstage and offstage theatrical positions and their responsibilities
  • actor
  • designer
  • director
  • playwright
  • producer
  • stage manager
  • technician
Identify characteristics of theatre spaces
Identify tools and equipment used in stagecraft

http://purl.org/ASN/schema/core/comment.value: e.g., construction tools, measurement tools, sewing machine

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Describe the uses of a variety of theatrical paperwork

http://purl.org/ASN/schema/core/comment.value: e.g., résumé, rehearsal schedule, audition forms

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Students will refine and complete artistic work.
Examine self and peer evaluations of artistic work
Performing
Students will analyze, interpret, and select artistic work for presentation.
Analyze a script of literary merit
Examine the manner in which character choices assist in telling the story of a drama/theatre work
Analyze characters and technical elements based on research from multiple sources of information

Define the elements of drama
  • character

Students will develop and refine artistic work for presentation.
Develop a believable, authentic, and relevant performance of a drama/theatre work through physical, vocal, and psychological choices

Develop theatrical skills and techniques through the rehearsal process
  • table work

  • analysis

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Students will convey meaning through the presentation of artistic work.
Convey a specific meaning through the performance of a devised or scripted drama/theatre work
Present an original theatrical design
Responding
Students will perceive and analyze artistic work.
Identify the consequences of a character's decisions and actions
Discuss the characteristics of authentic character interactions
Discuss the contribution of technical elements to the effectiveness of a production
Discuss dramatic elements of an observed drama/theatre work using basic theatre terminology
Respond appropriately to a theatrical experience as an audience member
Students will interpret intent and meaning in artistic work.
Identify emotional responses evoked by a variety of genres
Investigate the impact of technical design choices on the mood and meaning of a drama/theatre work
Students will apply criteria to evaluate artistic work.

Develop criteria using basic theatre terminology to evaluate performances and/or designs
  • peer
  • self
  • stage, film, and/or television
Distinguish between personal preferences and artistic merit
Connecting
Students will synthesize and relate knowledge and personal experiences to make art.
Analyze the impact of personal experience on the creation of drama/theatre work
Research acting theories (e.g., internal, external, integrated, method) utilizing technology
Students will relate artistic ideas and works with societal, cultural, and historical context to deepen understanding.
Research the societal, cultural, and historical contexts that lead to personal artistic choices
Research the influence of cultural perspectives on theatrical conventions/practices

http://purl.org/ASN/schema/core/comment.value: e.g., blackout represents passing of time, set with three walls represents an entire room, soliloquy represents character's internal monologue

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Investigate the effect of theatre on people of various ages and cultures
Discuss cultural sensitivity to the artistic work of others

Identify connections between theatre history and student-created drama/theatre work
